meanings.def: to move through the air, using wings
examples: Penguins can't fly.
+ adv./prep. A stork flew slowly past.
A wasp had flown in through the window.
Geese fly south in the fall.

meanings.def: to move through air or space
examples: fly (from A) (to B) They were on a plane flying from London to New York.
fly (to B) (from A) Lufthansa fly to La Paz from Frankfurt.
+ adv./prep. Enemy planes fly overhead.
to fly at the speed of sound
The aircraft was declared fully functional and fit to fly.

meanings.def: to travel in an aircraft or a spacecraft
examples: Is this the first time that you've flown?
fly (from A) (to B) I'm flying to Hong Kong tomorrow.
fly + adv./prep. I was flying home to visit my family.
+ noun I always fly business class.
We're flying KLM.

meanings.def: to control an aircraft, etc. in the air
examples: He's learning to fly.
fly something a pilot trained to fly large passenger planes
children flying kites
She's trained to fly passenger planes, not military jets.
You'll have to fly the helicopter over some dangerous territory.

meanings.def: to transport goods or passengers in a plane
examples: The stranded tourists were finally flown home.
He had flowers specially flown in for the ceremony.
Orders were given to fly the prisoners to the US.

meanings.def: to move through the air for a particular distance; to travel over an ocean or area of land in an aircraft
examples: Some birds fly huge distances when they migrate.
Who was the first person to fly the Atlantic?
Only four airlines are currently allowed to fly transatlantic routes from Heathrow.

meanings.def: to go or move quickly
examples: The train was flying along.
She gasped and her hand flew to her mouth.
It's late—I must fly.

meanings.def: to move suddenly and with force
examples: (+ adv./prep.) A large stone came flying in through the window.
Several people were hit by flying glass.
+ adj. David gave the door a kick and it flew open.

meanings.def: to seem to pass very quickly
examples: Doesn't time fly?
fly by/past Summer has just flown by.

meanings.def: if a flag flies, or if you fly it, it is displayed, for example on a pole (= a long piece of wood or metal)
examples: Flags were flying at half mast on all public buildings.
fly something to fly the Stars and Stripes

meanings.def: to move around freely
examples: hair flying in the wind

meanings.def: to be talked about by many people
to escape from somebody/something
examples: Both suspects have flown the country.

meanings.def: to be successful
examples: It remains to be seen whether his project will fly.

meanings.def: to hit a ball high into the air
in a straight line
examples: The villages are no more than a mile apart as the crow flies.

meanings.def: the wanted person has escaped
to act without careful thought and without a plan that you have made in advance, hoping that you will be lucky and be successful
to escape from a place
to show your support for your country, an organization or an idea to encourage or persuade others to do the same
to be successful
examples: British cinema has been flying high recently, winning several coveted awards.

meanings.def: to oppose or be the opposite of something that is usual or expected
examples: Such a proposal is flying in the face of common sense.

meanings.def: to become suddenly very angry
to test out public opinion on a subject
examples: The company is flying a kite to see if this plan provokes any interest.

meanings.def: to become able to fly and leave its nest
to leave home and live somewhere else
examples: Her children have flown the nest.

meanings.def: to suddenly start saying or doing something that does not seem to be connected to what has gone before
examples: He never sticks to the point but keeps going off at a tangent.
Laura’s mind went off at a tangent.

meanings.def: to suddenly become very angry
examples: He seems to fly off the handle about the slightest thing these days.

meanings.def: to stop existing; to disappear completely
examples: As soon as the kids arrived, order went out of the window.

meanings.def: to fall, especially as a result of not seeing something under your feet
examples: Someone's going to go flying if you don't pick up these toys.

meanings.def: used to tell somebody to go away and stop annoying you or interfering
to represent your country or organization
examples: Our exporters keep the flag flying at international trade exhibitions.

meanings.def: to attack somebody by hitting them or speaking angrily to them
examples: He let fly at me with his fist.
She let fly with a stream of abuse.

meanings.def: used to show that you do not believe something will ever happen
examples: ‘With a bit of luck, we'll be finished by the end of the year.’ ‘Yes, and pigs might fly!’

meanings.def: time seems to pass very quickly
examples: How time flies! I've got to go now.
Time has flown since the holiday began.

idioms.def: in a straight line
examples: The villages are no more than a mile apart as the crow flies.

idioms.def: the wanted person has escaped

idioms.idiom: (fly) by the seat of your pants
idioms.def: to act without careful thought and without a plan that you have made in advance, hoping that you will be lucky and be successful
to escape from a place
to show your support for your country, an organization or an idea to encourage or persuade others to do the same
to be successful
examples: British cinema has been flying high recently, winning several coveted awards.

idioms.idiom: fly in the face of something
idioms.def: to oppose or be the opposite of something that is usual or expected
examples: Such a proposal is flying in the face of common sense.

idioms.idiom: fly into a rage, temper, etc.
idioms.def: to become suddenly very angry
to test out public opinion on a subject
examples: The company is flying a kite to see if this plan provokes any interest.

idioms.def: to become able to fly and leave its nest
examples: Her children have flown the nest.

idioms.def: to suddenly start saying or doing something that does not seem to be connected to what has gone before
examples: He never sticks to the point but keeps going off at a tangent.
Laura’s mind went off at a tangent.

idioms.def: to suddenly become very angry
examples: He seems to fly off the handle about the slightest thing these days.

idioms.def: to stop existing; to disappear completely
examples: As soon as the kids arrived, order went out of the window.

idioms.def: to fall, especially as a result of not seeing something under your feet
examples: Someone's going to go flying if you don't pick up these toys.

idioms.def: used to tell somebody to go away and stop annoying you or interfering
to represent your country or organization
examples: Our exporters keep the flag flying at international trade exhibitions.

idioms.def: to attack somebody by hitting them or speaking angrily to them
examples: He let fly at me with his fist.
She let fly with a stream of abuse.

idioms.def: used to show that you do not believe something will ever happen
examples: ‘With a bit of luck, we'll be finished by the end of the year.’ ‘Yes, and pigs might fly!’

idioms.def: time seems to pass very quickly
examples: How time flies! I've got to go now.
Time has flown since the holiday began.

meanings.def: a small flying insect with two wings. There are many different types of fly and many of them spread disease.
examples: A fly was buzzing against the window.
Flies rose in thick black swarms.
A fly settled on the butter.
I swatted the fly with a newspaper.

meanings.def: a fly or something made to look like a fly, that is put on the end of a fishing line and used as bait to catch fish
examples: fly fishing

meanings.def: an opening down the front of a pair of trousers that fastens with a zip or buttons and is usually covered over by a narrow piece of material
examples: Your fly is undone!
Your flies are undone!

meanings.def: a piece of material that covers the entrance to a tent
a ball that is hit high into the air
to die or become ill and fall down in very large numbers
examples: People were dropping like flies in the intense heat.

meanings.def: a person or thing that makes a situation or an occasion less pleasant, successful, etc.
a person who watches others without being noticed
examples: I'd love to be a fly on the wall when he tells her the news.
fly-on-the-wall documentaries (= in which people are filmed going about their normal lives as if the camera were not there)

meanings.def: the person mentioned is clever and not easily tricked
to be kind and gentle and unwilling to cause unhappiness
if you do something on the fly, you do it quickly while something else is happening, and without thinking about it very much
while a computer program or application is operating, without completely restarting it
examples: Now, while I'm on the desktop, I can switch between open apps on the fly.

idioms.def: to die or become ill and fall down in very large numbers
examples: People were dropping like flies in the intense heat.

idioms.def: a person or thing that makes a situation or an occasion less pleasant, successful, etc.
a person who watches others without being noticed
examples: I'd love to be a fly on the wall when he tells her the news.
fly-on-the-wall documentaries (= in which people are filmed going about their normal lives as if the camera were not there)

idioms.def: the person mentioned is clever and not easily tricked
to be kind and gentle and unwilling to cause unhappiness
if you do something on the fly, you do it quickly while something else is happening, and without thinking about it very much
examples: Now, while I'm on the desktop, I can switch between open apps on the fly.

meanings.def: clever and showing good judgement about people, especially so that you can get an advantage for yourself
fashionable and attractive
